questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents 4 weeks after delivery with failure of lactation, visual disturbances, amenorrhea and cold intolerance. She is found to have hypoglycemia and hypotension. Which drug should be given first in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hydrocortisone Postpartum pituitary apoplexy is known as Sheehan's syndrome Treatment involves hormone replacement and treatment of the underlying cause. Hydrocortisone for secondary adrenal failure. Thyroxine if hypothyroid. Hypogonadism (for symptoms and to prevent osteoporosis).

questions.text: Excess prolactin can cause the production of breast milk in men and in women who are not pregnant or breastfeeding. In women, too much prolactin can also cause menstrual problems and infertility. In men, it can lead to lower sex drive and erectile dysfunction (ED). All are causes of hyperprolactinemia, except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bromocriptine Causes of hyperprolactinemia 1 Physiological: Pregnancy; breast-feeding; stress eg post-seizure. Drugs (most common cause): Phenothiazine; Metoclopramide; Haloperidol, Methyldopa; estrogens - 3. Diseases: Prolactinoma: micro- or macroadenoma; 4. Stalk damage: pituitary adenomas, surgery, trauma; craniopharyngioma. 5. Other: Hypothyroidism, CRF.

questions.text: Patients with the following MRI findings also have a lab investigation of an increase in prolactin level. What will you do next?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Transsphenoidal surgery The MRI of this patient shows a coronal t1 weighted post-contrast magnetic resonance image, there shows a homogeneously enhanced mass (arrows) in the sella turcica and suprasellar region compatible with a pituitary adenoma The small arrows outline the carotid arteries The lab diagnosis of an increase in the prolactin levels points towards a prolactinoma and confirms the diagnosis of pituitary adenoma. The preferred surgery is transsphenoidal rather than the trans frontal resection except for the rare invasive suprasellar mass surrounding the frontal or middle portion of the optic nerves or invading posteriorly behind the clivus Hence transsphenoidal surgery is the surgery of choice

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B Trans frontal resection Transfrontal resection is not preferred unless there is a rare invasive suprasellar mass surrounding the frontal or middle portion of the optic nerves or invading posteriorly behind the clivus Option: C - Radiation Radiation is not applied and is referred to as primary therapy in this case However, it is preferred as an adjunct to the surgical therapy Option: D Wait for further lab investigation Here the MRI shows a coronal t1 weighted post-contrast magnetic resonance image, there shows a homogeneously enhanced mass (arrows) in the sella turcica and suprasellar region compatible with a pituitary adenoma There is also clinical evidence of increased prolactin levels causing a prolactinoma hence we have to proceed with the surgery rather than wait for the lab investigation

questions.text: The patient, female 24 years old, there is a discharge of milk containing fluid from her breast after discontinuing breastfeeding 7 months ago .elevated prolactin levels were found and further investigations revealed the presence of microadenoma. What will you do next?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Titrate dopamine agonist Here the patient has a discharge of milk-containing fluid after discontinuation of breastfeeding for greater than 6 months This means the patient is having galactorrhea Also, the patient was shown to have an increase in prolactin levels considering prolactinoma and there is microadenoma Here the mainstay of treatment is an oral dopamine agonist for patients with micro or macro adenoma Dopamine agonists are going to suppress PRL secretion and synthesis as well as lactotrope cell proliferation In patients with microadenoma who have achieved normal prolactin levels and significant reduction of tumour mass, dopamine agonists may be withdrawn after 2 years

questions.text: A 15 yr old male presented with micropenis, decreased libido, reduced body hair, reduced muscle mass and anosmia. He was suspected of a case of Kallmann syndrome. All are true about this condition except?

options.label: C
options.text: High levels of FSH and LH

questions.correct_answer: C. High levels of FSH and LH
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High levels of FSH and LH This clinical scenario suggests a case of Kallmann syndrome. It is associated with Anosmia. It is characterized by low luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels and low concentrations of sex steroids (testosterone or estradiol). It is a diagnosis of exclusion.

Highyeild:

Kallmann's Syndrome It is a form of Hypogonadotrophic Hypogonadism (HH). Failure of communication between hypothalamus and the anterior pituitary gland. Hypothalamic neurons (GNRH D hypothalamus during to migrate into the development. Clinical Features: Puberty failure Lack of testicle development in men Primary amenorrhea or failure to start menstruation • Poorly defined secondary sexual characteristics Infertility Cleft palate or other craniofacial defects. Anosmia or hyposmia Investigations: Low serum testosterone Low serum estrogens Low levels of LH and FSH Karyotype X-ray MRI Mode of inheritanching Genetic mutations in the KAL-I gene (X-linked) or as an autosomal dominant or recessive fashion. Treatment: Menstruation can be induced with combined estrogen and progestin therapy. Induction of ovulation is successful with exogenous gonadotropins.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A : Kallmann syndrome results from defective hypothalamic gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) synthesis and is associated with anosmia or hyposmia due to olfactory bulb agenesis or hypoplasia. The syndrome may also be associated with colour blindness, optic atrophy, nerve deafness, cleft palate, renal abnormalities, cryptorchidism, and neurologic abnormalities such as mirror movements. Option B: A gene involved was the X-linked KAL gene, mutations of which impair embryonic migration of GnRH neurons from the hypothalamic olfactory placode to the hypothalamus. Autosomal recessive and dominant are also described Option D: GnRH deficiency prevents progression through puberty. Males present with delayed puberty and pronounced hypogonadal features due to low testosterone levels during infancy. Females present with primary amenorrhea and failure of secondary sexual development.

Extraedge:

Repetitive GnRH administration restores normal pituitary gonadotropin responses. Long-term treatment of males with human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) or testosterone restores pubertal development and secondary sex characteristics; women can be treated with cyclic estrogen and progestin.

questions.text: A 10-year-old mentally retarded obese child was brought for increased consumption of foods. On examination hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and hypotonia were present. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prader Willi syndrome The clinical scenario of obesity, mental retardation and chronic muscle hypotonia is suggestive of Prader-Willi syndrome. This syndrome is associated with unimaternal disomy. This syndrome results from the deletion of the paternal copies of the SNRPN gene, NECDIN gene and chromosome 15q. It presents with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, hyperphagia-obesity, chronic muscle hypotonia, mental retardation, and adult-onset diabetes mellitus. Chronic GnRH treatment restores pituitary LH and FSH release.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B: Kallmann syndrome results from defective hypothalamic gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) synthesis, presents with anosmia or hyposmia, hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism, renal abnormalities, cryptorchidism, and neurologic abnormalities such as mirror movements. Option C: Bardet Biedll syndrome is characterized by intellectual disability, renal abnormalities, obesity, and hexadactyly, brachydactyly, or syndactyly. Retinal degeneration begins in early childhood, and most patients are blind by age 30. Option D: Midline cerebral defect syndrome presentation varies with abnormal development of the eyes, corpus callosum, vertebrae, and genital systems. Pituitary dysfunction also can be isolated or combined with pituitary hormone deficiency (CPHD) and diabetes insipidus (DI)

questions.text: The 10-year-old child presented with frequent episodes of giddiness. On examination short stature, micropenis and high-pitched voice were present. The blood sugar levels were very low. Childhood-onset Growth hormone deficiency was suspected. All are stimulatory tests to conclude except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Metyrapone test The clinical scenario suggests growth hormone deficiency Metyrapone test is used to detect ACTH deficiency, 30 mg/kg is given at midnight and plasma 11 deoxycortisol and cortisol is measured at 8 am, the normal response is 11 deoxycortisol >7. 5 μg/dL, plasma cortisol <4g/dl. So, this test can be used to detect Cushing’s disease.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B: In patients with GH deficiency, IGF-1 levels are low to normal The most validated test is insulin-induced (0. 05–0. 1 U/kg) hypoglycemia. After glucose reduction to ~40 mg/dL, most individuals experience neuroglycopenic symptoms and peak GH release occurs at 60 min and remains elevated for up to 2 h. About 90% of healthy adults exhibit GH responses >5 μg/L; in growth hormone deficiency, peak GH response to hypoglycemia is <3 μg/L. It is contraindicated in patients with diabetes, ischemic heart disease, cerebrovascular disease, or epilepsy and in elderly patients. GHRH 1 μg/kg IV oral ghrelin receptor agonist (0. 5 mg/kg), glucagon (1 mg) Option C: In the l-dopa test, 500mg is given orally leading to an increase in GH >3 μg/L. Option D: Intravenous arginine 30g over 30 minutes also leads to an increase in GH > 3μg/L

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presented with headache, vomiting, weight gain and sleep disturbance. Eye examination revealed papilledema. A CT scan shows calcification. Laboratory investigation shows a feature of hypopituitarism. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Craniopharyngioma Craniopharyngiomas are benign, suprasellar cystic masses that present with headaches, visual field deficits, and variable degrees of hypopituitarism. They are derived from Rathke’s pouch and arise near the pituitary stalk Craniopharyngiomas are large, cystic, and locally invasive, partially calcified, exhibiting a characteristic appearance on skull X-ray and CT images. Present with headache, vomiting, papilledema, and hydrocephalus. Associated symptoms include visual field abnormalities, personality changes and cognitive deterioration, cranial nerve damage, sleep difficulties, and weight gain. Hypopituitarism is documented in the majority while, and diabetes insipidus is less common CT/MRI helps in the diagnosis.

Highyeild:

Treatment usually involves transcranial or transsphenoidal surgical resection followed by postoperative radiation of residual tumou Most patients require lifelong pituitary hormone replacement. In patients with BRAF mutations, the use of BRAF inhibitors (dabrafenib or vemurafenib) either alone or in combination with MEK inhibitors (trametinib or cobimetinib) can be used.

In acromegaly, Acral bony overgrowth results in frontal bossing, increased hand and foot size, mandibular enlargement with prognathism, and widened space between the lower incisor teeth. Soft tissue swelling results in increased heel pad thickness, increased shoe or glove size, ring tightening, characteristic coarse facial features, and a large fleshy nose. Others include hyperhidrosis, a deep and hollow-sounding voice, oily skin, arthropathy, kyphosis, carpal tunnel syndrome, proximal muscle weakness and fatigue, acanthosis nigricans, and skin tags Option: C. Developmental failure of Rathke’s pouch obliteration may lead to Rathke’s cysts, which are small (< 5 mm) cysts entrapped by squamous epithelium, diagnosed incidentally, few patients present with compressive symptoms, diabetes insipidus, and hyperprolactinemia due to stalk compression. The diagnosis is suggested preoperatively by visualizing the cyst wall on MRI, which distinguishes these lesions from craniopharyngiomas. Option: D. Bardet Biedll syndrome is characterized by intellectual disability, renal abnormalities, obesity, and hexadactyly, brachydactyly, or syndactyly. Retinal degeneration begins in early childhood, and most patients are blind by age 30.

questions.text: All are genetic syndromes associated with pituitary tumours except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gardner syndrome It presents with colonic polyps, osteomas and soft tissue tumours Autosomal dominant with a mutation in APC gene loci 5q21. Gardner syndrome is a variant of FAP (Familial adenomatous polyposis) It also presents with epidermoid cysts, fibroma, neurofibroma, lipoma, leiomyoma and pigmented skin lesions. Desmoid tumours can occur over the abdominal wall and are resistant to treatment. Retinal pigment layer hypertrophy can occur. Other manifestations are papillary thyroid cancer, meningioma, hepatoma, hepatoblastoma, osteosarcoma and chondrosarcoma

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A: Multiple endocrine neoplasias (MEN) 1 is an autosomal dominant syndrome characterized primarily by a genetic predisposition to parathyroid, pancreatic islet, and pituitary adenomas. MEN 1 is caused by inactivating germline mutations in MENIN, a constitutively expressed tumour-suppressor gene located on chromosome 11q13. Option B: Carney complex is characterized by spotty skin pigmentation, myxomas, and endocrine tumours, including testicular, adrenal, and pituitary adenomas. Mutations in the R1α regulatory subunit of protein kinase A (PRKAR1A) are present Option C: McCune-Albright syndrome consists of polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, pigmented skin patches, and a variety of endocrine disorders, including acromegaly, adrenal adenomas, and autonomous ovarian function. Hormonal hypersecretion results from constitutive cyclic AMP production caused by the inactivation of the GTPase activity of Gs α.

questions.text: The 15-year-old male child presented with hyperhidrosis, oily skin, and acanthosis nigricans. On examination frontal bossing, prognathism and increased heel pad thickness were present. IGF 1 level and growth hormone are elevated. All are true about the condition except?

options.label: A
options.text: Pituitary adenoma is the most common cause

options.label: B
options.text: In untreated patients, Cardiomyopathy with arrhythmia may occur

options.label: D
options.text: Diagnosis confirmed by GH suppression test with oral glucose

questions.correct_answer: C. Visceromegaly is not a feature
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Visceromegaly is not a feature The clinical scenario suggests acromegaly. In acromegaly, Acral bony overgrowth results in frontal bossing, increased hand and foot size, mandibular enlargement with prognathism, and widened space between the lower incisor teeth. Soft tissue swelling results in increased heel pad thickness, increased shoe or glove size, ring tightening, characteristic coarse facial features, and a large fleshy nose. Others include hyperhidrosis, a deep and hollow-sounding voice, oily skin, arthropathy, kyphosis, carpal tunnel syndrome, proximal muscle weakness and fatigue, acanthosis nigricans, and skin tags. Generalized visceromegaly occurs, including cardiomegaly, macroglossia, and thyroid gland enlargement. It can also be associated with increased thickness of jaw bone and also increased size of carpals, metacarpals and phalanges.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. It is associated with excess growth hormone secretion in pituitary adenoma which is the most common cause of acromegaly. Also associated with MEN 1, mccune Albright syndrome, pancreatic islet cell tumour and lymphoma. Option: B. The most significant clinical impact of GH excess occurs with respect to the cardiovascular system. Cardiomyopathy with arrhythmias left ventricular hypertrophy, decreased diastolic function, hypertension ultimately occurs in most patients if untreated. Upper airway obstruction with sleep apnea is associated with both soft tissue laryngeal airway obstruction and central sleep dysfunction. Diabetes mellitus is intolerant to glucose load (as GH counteracts the action of insulin). Acromegaly is associated with an increased risk of colon polyps and mortality from colonic malignancy Option: D. Age-matched serum IGF-1 levels are elevated in acromegaly. The diagnosis of acromegaly is confirmed by demonstrating the failure of GH suppression to <0. 4 μg/L within 1–2 h of an oral glucose load (75 g).

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presented with polyuria, increased thirst and nocturia. 24 hour urinary volume, osmolarity and AVP was 50ml/kg, 800 mosml/L and 0. 5pg/ml respectively. Brain MRI shows a pituitary bright spot. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Primary polydipsia It occurs due to the suppression of AVP secretion by excessive intake of fluids. It is commonly referred to as primary polydipsia and can be subdivided into three subcategories. Dipsogenic DI, the excessive fluid intake appears to be caused by inappropriate thirst. It can occur following head trauma or in association with multifocal diseases of the brain such as neurosarcoid, tuberculous meningitis, and multiple sclerosis Psychogenic polydipsia, is not associated with thirst, and polydipsia seems to be a feature of psychosis or obsessive-compulsive disorder. Latrogenic polydipsia, is due to an increase in water intake motivated by a belief in its health benefits. Brain MRI can be performed to determine if the hyperintense signal normally emitted by the posterior pituitary on T1- weighted images is present. Because this "bright spot" is a function of pituitary stores of AVP, it is almost always present in primary polydipsia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A: In nephrogenic DI, AVP is normal or elevated (>1 pg/mL) and the concurrent urine osmolarity is low (<280 mosm/L). Basal plasma AVP is low or undetectable (<1 pg/mL), and nephrogenic DI is very unlikely. The bright spot is also faint or absent in nephrogenic DI presumably because the chronic stimulus to AVP secretion depletes pituitary stores of the hormone. Option C: It occurs due to a deficiency of AVP caused by an increased rate of degradation by an N-terminal aminopeptidase produced in the placenta. It is referred to as gestational DI because the signs and symptoms manifest during pregnancy and usually remit several weeks after delivery. Option D: Brain MRI can be performed to determine if the hyperintense signal normally emitted by the posterior pituitary on T1-weighted images, "bright spot" t is abnormally small or absent in pituitary DI even when the deficiency in AVP is partial or due to production of a biologically inactive form of the hormone
